Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Towards Building Time Capsule for Online Social Activities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The capability to preserve, model, and predict information cascades over online social networks has many theoretical and practical implications, e.g., for marketing, recommendation filtering, and studying of societal behavior. Massive empirical data sets on users' online social activities are being collected, but they are often too big to analyze. The goal of this project is to design graph generative models and summarization techniques that can preserve pertinent information about online social interactions that lead to interesting events, e.g., viral diffusion of information or drastic change of user behavior. Towards this end, the project will develop generative models that can capture the dynamic evolution of user activity graphs (UAGs), which represent a sequence of inter-user communications/actions. At the microscopic level, the project will investigate user influence in the recruitment process. In addition, the project will design graph summarization techniques that can achieve good tradeoffs between data compression ratio, computational complexities, and accuracy in answering fundamental queries, such as identifying 'influential' sources of information cascades.

Broader Impact: If successful, this project will provide efficient methods for storing/archiving massive graph data to support longitudinal study on the dynamics of online social interactions, which has potential impact on multiple disciplines (e.g., economics, history, political sciences, and social science). This project will help train future researchers and practitioners in online social networking and network science through classroom curriculum development and online teaching. The PIs will continue ongoing diversity recruitment and outreach to K-12 students. Transfer of technology into commercial practice is made feasible through partnership with industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The massive ecosystem of content generation, sharing, and consumption over online social platforms has huge implications on how information propagates and influences user behavior. Being able to preserve, model, and predict information cascades over online social networks will have many theoretical and practical implications, e.g., for marketing, recommendation filtering, and studying of societal behavior. By analyzing massive empirical data sets on users' online social activities, our project aims to achieve three objectives: (1) model diffusion process over online social media and develop learning-based models for predicting both macroscopic properties (e.g., forecasting future active user population size), or microscopic user behavior (e.g., predicting the likelihood of a user to adopt an idea/application); (2) capture cascades and co-evolution across networks and relationships between contents, and (3) developed efficient algorithms to compress user activity graphs using a combination of sketching and sampling for answering the most common queries regarding information cascades. user influence in the recruitment process.

Our characterization of anonymized user interaction data over OSN-gifting applications revealed that the evolutionary properties of cascades (e.g., initial growth rate) are good predictors of the ultimate cascade sizes. Our predictive model can achieve high precision (70-95%) for classifying application adoption cascades as small, medium, or large using observed activities in the first four weeks. Our micro-level analysis of how user influence one another and the roles played by users provides insights on future user behavior. We found that the average success ratio of inviters is the most important feature for predicting whether an invitee will adopt a new application or not. We also applied deep learning techniques for extracting image features that can be used for predicting popular or viral image cascades.  Our results show that image meta and pinner features are the strongest predictor in predicting popular image cascades. We successfully developed a memory-based deep recurrent network called Diffusion-LSTM that learns to recursively predict the entire diffusion path of an image through a social network. A better forecasting of information cascades has implications on resource provisioning of networks/data centers as well as marketing strategies.

In analyzing co-evolving multiplex networks, we applied Multiplex Markov chain to quantify correlations in edge dynamics found in longitudinal data of multiplex network. We establish the existence of "dynamical spillover" showing the correlated formation (or deletion) of edges of different types as the system evolves. We also demonstrated that the notion of topic networks (that reflect the collective opinions of other like-minded users) is useful in accurately predicting a user’s interest and behavioral pattern in Pinterest.  Our work on uncovering relationships between topics/content shared over online social media has potential impact on business analytics, including marketing and advertising strategies, and product recommendation.

Early on in our project, we demonstrated that existing graph sampling and streaming algorithms are ineffective in preserving important characteristics of information cascades over OSN graphs. We proposed a measurement method, ForestStream, that relies on a combination of sampling and streaming with the goal of capturing the statistical properties of cascades in OSN graphs. ForestStream performs well even when given the same amount of memory as the other graph sampling methods. We also provided theoretical guarantees of the inference accuracy in capturing OSN cascade statistics.

This project has graduated two PhD and eight (including six female) MS students and involved several undergraduate student researchers. It also provided training for a postdoc who is now an Assistant Professor in Asia. Postdoc, graduate, and undergraduate students are being trained in various fundamental topics, including data collection/analysis, data mining, statistical inference, graph sampling/streaming, and complex networks. They have been exposed to cutting edge research on the topic of online social networks and recommendation systems. Since this project involves collaboration with industry and multiple PIs with different expertise, the postdoc/students learn to work in a multi-disciplinary team.

Through collaboration with our industry partners, we have applied our measurement and analysis techniques on a variety of data sets from Facebook, Twitter, and Pinterest. The anonymized data can be found at: https://www.ece.ucdavis.edu/~chuah/rubinet/data.html.  Our results have been disseminated via publications/presentations in conferences, invited seminars, as well as through our project website: http://www.ece.ucdavis.edu/~chuah/rubinet/projects/zip-osn.html.
